instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi.

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which had a burnt J3501.

[ATTACH type="full" width="291px" alt="s-l1600.jpg"]59269[/ATTACH]

This has now been removed. Not sure how this happened and why it burnt as no other components have been effected.

I've also remove the JTAG as this had a small amount of corrosion and I've replaced <CAPACITOR>C3287</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R3561</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3560</CAPACITOR> & <CHIP>U3560</CHIP> just for giggles.

I'm missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, some readings

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> triggered drops <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> to 0v

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> pulse from 0v to 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulse from 0v to 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse from 0v to 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulse from 0v to 3.4v
L7310 - pulse from 0v to 3.4v
L7320 - pulse from 0v to 3.4v

I'm also getting pulse on the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, pins 3,5 and 6

Not sure what else to check and why <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8v"
Please post EXACT volatge.
I doubt you have 8.00V there; and 8.2V will means something completely different than 8.4V!

"L7310 - pulse from 0v to 3.4v
L7320 - pulse from 0v to 3.4v"
Are you really sure???
VCORE cannot go up than 1.8V.
Please post accurate inbformation.

If you get pulse at pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, check if <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulse at same time.

If had corrosion around J6100, check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
If all good, then try known good working BIOS.

Worth to try starting in SMC bypass first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
My bad.. I just cut and pasted the L7310/20 - it's pulsing 0v to 1.6v

PPBUS - 8.55v
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses 0v to 3.3v

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> 
pin 1 - 3.3v
pin 2 - 3.3v
pin 3 - 3.3v
pin 4 - 0.0v
pin 5 - 3.3v
pin 6 - 3.3v
pin 7 - 3.3v
pin 8 - 3.3v

No difference with SMC bypass - will try a working BIOS when I find one.

Any thing else I can check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you note a drop pulse at pins 5/6 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>?
At same time when <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulses.
Don't forget to check mentioned resistors and traces...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Both pins 5/6 pulse 3.3v to 0 then back up to 3.3v 

All resistors and traces are fine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
There are more than 20 SPI resistors, don't miss any...

We have clean ME BIOS already poste on the forum.
Try this one too,
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/10PQbSQ8wrvXxrLrXypNT0Mtwnzq5coXt/view?usp=sharing[/URL]
as is, just for test; do NOT change ssn yet.

threads.message: Just finished reprogramming the BIOS with a new working version - clean ME

threads.message: I will try your BIOS and see if it makes any difference

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Didn't work with your file and I've doubled checked all resistors and traces nothing found

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"no other components have been effected."
<CHIP>U3560</CHIP> is directly connected with PCH, it could be affected too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes I've checked that with a working board and they are the same. (there was no liquid or burn near to it) I think I will have to put this down to a PCH fault as I don't know what to try next unless you have any suggestions..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Looks like PCH issue, which is same as CPU here :(
